Award.AwardTitle: INSPIRE: Exploring living system responses to quantum states of light
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is jointly funded by the following programs in the Divisions of Physics (PHY) and Chemistry (CHE) of the Directorate for Mathematics and Physical Sciences (MPS), and the Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences (BCS) of the Directorate for Social and Behavioral and Economic Sciences (SBE), with co-funding from the Office of Integrative Activities: MPS/PHY/Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics--Experiment, MPS/PHY/Physics of Living Systems, MPS/CHE/Chemistry of Life Processes, SBE/BCS/Program on Perception, Action, and Cognition and the SBE Office of Multidisciplinary Activities. This project will test the limits of how living things detect light and study how the laws of quantum mechanics apply to biological systems. Single photons (individual particles of light) will be used to study both the human visual system and light-sensitive bacteria. In the human visual system, this project will determine whether humans can see a single photon (a longstanding question in psychology) by using a method of creating one photon at a time to test the vision of human observers. This project will also investigate what human observers see when they detect a photon in a superposition - a state of being in two places at the same time - which is allowed by quantum mechanics. Light-sensitive bacteria will also be studied using single photons, to understand the limits of light detection and the possible effects of quantum laws in a different biological system. In addition to advancing our knowledge of how living things detect and use light, this research might help us understand why particles such as photons show strange quantum behavior such as superposition, while the familiar world around us behaves differently. Making quantum effects available to human perception would also have broad popular appeal, and could be a gateway for students and the public to learn about quantum physics.

To produce single photons, this project will use a well-known heralded single-photon source design based on spontaneous parametric downconversion. Single photons at 505 nm and 440 nm will be used for experiments with humans and E. coli, respectively. To determine whether humans can see single photons, observers will complete a series of trials in which they must choose whether the stimulus photon appeared on the left or the right side of their visual field. If observers are able to choose left or right with accuracy statistically greater than 50%, this is strong evidence that they can see single photons. An EEG-contingent stimulus delivery method will also be developed to improve the likelihood of detection. If single-photon vision is confirmed, a subsequent experiment will attempt a test of quantum nonlocality with a human observer replacing one single-photon detector. Finally, to test perception of superposition states, observers will be presented with both a classical mixture of photons at the left and right spots, and photons in a superposition of left and right. The observer's frequency of choosing left and right will be compared between the two cases, with any unexpected difference suggesting a deviation from standard quantum mechanics. To study phototactic bacteria (which move in response to light), individual E. coli cells will be immobilized in an IR optical trap and stimulated with single photons. In an established technique, the response of the cells can be measured by tracking their swimming and tumbling behavior with the trapping beam. Other species will be studied in following experiments, including photosynthetic Rhodobacter sphaeroides.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We are an interdisciplinary team of physicists and psychologists studying how light interacts with biological systems. The goals of this project were to use classical and quantum light to study two very different biological systems: the human visual system and the movement of bacteria in response to light (phototaxis).

PHOTOTAXIS

While blue light has been shown to elicit a tumbling response in Escherichia coli (E. coli), the exact mechanism of this phototactic response is still unknown. Towards determining this mechanism, we built and developed methods to enable bright-source phototaxis experiments at the single-cell and population levels. We isolated all five E. coli receptors and showed that they are all capable of mediating responses to light. We also provided evidence to support that E. coli use chemoreceptors to sense light-induced perturbations in proton motive force, rather than sensing light directly. These findings are important because they provide new insights into the mechanism of E. coli phototaxis. The results also open new avenues for examining and manipulating E. coli taxis.

HUMAN VISUAL STUDY

In the human vision branch of this project, we are working to determine whether humans can detect single photons. We first implemented our source to study the temporal summation window of the eye and how this window expands under extremely low photon numbers (Holmes et al., 2017). Temporal summation describes how the visual system combines visual signals that arrive at different times, in order to send a stronger neural signal to the brain. Depending on the sum of many individual inputs, summation may or may not reach the threshold voltage to trigger an action potential. Previous studies used dim pulses of coherent light (meaning that each pulse contained a Poissonian distribution of photons). These studies estimated complete summation to last for 100 ms. Our study, however, benefited from our robust single-photon source, as it allowed us to measure the full range of temporal summation for much weaker and controlled stimuli. By sending a stream of photons delivered at a constant rate to our observers, we estimated the maximal temporal integration window to be 650 ms on average (much longer than the previous studies). This relatively long integration window informed the experimental design for our study of the absolute visual threshold ? with such a long integration window, we needed to ensure that single photons themselves should be separated adequately to avoi summation.

Due to a number of experimental setbacks, we are currently in the middle of our final data collection. A previous study (Tinsley et al., 2016) demonstrated statistically significant accuracy with a test somewhat similar to ours, also employing a two-alternative forced choice protocol, but instead of asking subjects to determine where they saw the stimulus (as we do), they asked when. With 2,420 overall single-photon trials, they saw subjects register high-confidence 10% of the time, corresponding to 242 high-confidence trials that saw an accuracy of 60% We are confident that our replication will produce interesting results as our source has a heralding efficiency of 27% (Tinsley's source only reached a 20% heralding efficiency), and hope to complete data acquisition within the next few months.

OUTREACH

As part of our outreach effort to enhance public interest in physics and optics, we have continued running our science-based 'escape room', LabEscape, at a local mall.  (For more details see LabEscape.org). Participants work through a series of puzzles teaching physics concepts with the goal of "unlocking" the door to escape the room within an hour. Creation of the room had support from the UI Department of Physics, the College of Engineering, the American Physical Society, and most recently the National Science Foundation. Over 8000 people experienced LabEscape. We also created a ~portable version of our science-based escape room that we brought to several conferences, including the 2018 annual American Association of Physics Teachers meeting in DC, and the 2019 APS March meeting and DAMOP annual conference. Over the summers in 2016-2019, we were able to run up to 500 high-school STEM students through LabEscape; additionally, PI Kwiat and several of the student volunteers interacted with ~10,000 people at our local farmer's market and town fairs, introducing them to various physics concepts, e.g., energy of photons, and using an IR-camera.
